title: IRC Archive for channel #xwiki on 24 November 2008 - XWiki
content:
Denis - (24/11/2008 10:43): Hi all, I ask again, since the WE was so quiet. Anyone here knows why groovy code require the author of the including doc (not as I have expected, the content doc) to have programming rights ? This put a major restriction, since object sheet could not execute groovy code, when the object document is not created by a user having programming rights. Example, rendering XWikiUserSheet with groovy code is not possible. And this is not what the API check does to pr asyd - (24/11/2008 10:47): you may don't need programming rights, regarding which API you use asyd - (24/11/2008 10:47): but anyway it's a good thing to restrict the usage of groovy, otherwise users are able to do what they want Denis - (24/11/2008 10:48): asyd: to run any groovy code, up to now, you should have programming rights, and these rights are currently tested on the author of the including doc, not the security doc asyd - (24/11/2008 10:49): hmm ok Denis - (24/11/2008 10:49): this is opposed to the restriction access done for accessing the priviledged API, which is check on the security doc (sdoc) Denis - (24/11/2008 10:50): this makes the usage of groovy really restricted or tricky Denis - (24/11/2008 10:50): so I wonder if there is any reason for that, or if this is a bug ? asyd - (24/11/2008 10:51): hmm, tried the mailing lists? Denis - (24/11/2008 10:51): not yet :) xwikibot - (24/11/2008 11:48): XWiki.XWikiServerXeclipse was modified by XWiki.RaffaelloPelagalli (Added object) - http://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/XWiki/XWikiServerXeclipse xwikibot - (24/11/2008 11:48): XWiki.XWikiServerXeclipse was modified by XWiki.RaffaelloPelagalli - http://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/XWiki/XWikiServerXeclipse xwikibot - (24/11/2008 13:06): XWiki.LucivanaFroes was modified by XWiki.LucivanaFroes (Created user) - http://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/XWiki/LucivanaFroes asiri - (24/11/2008 13:26): vmassol: Following xwiki/2.0 code \*\*Cost:\*\* is this correct ? Basically i need to bold the whole Cost: part, how do i do that ? asiri - (24/11/2008 13:27): ok, \*\*Cost~:\*\* vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:27): asiri: ah I see asiri - (24/11/2008 13:27): but this : Cost: asiri - (24/11/2008 13:27): :( vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:27): cost:xxx is considered an URI asiri - (24/11/2008 13:28): ohh, same issue we discussed earlier ? :) asiri - (24/11/2008 13:28): (vmassol) vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:28): I would have thought it would work though since after ":" there was \*\* and not some normal text vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:28): don't know what earlier is vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:28): but yes vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:28): this format: vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:28): scheme:something vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:29): is a link vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:29): hmmm that said I thought we were supporting only some uris vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:29): let me check vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:29): I think there might be something wrong here vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:29): (asiri) vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:29): since normally only "mailto:", "attach:" and "image:" are valid URIs asiri - (24/11/2008 13:30): previously we hadd a problem with

example:hi

... which is converted into example://hi which is scheme://something format asiri - (24/11/2008 13:30): it hought it has to be (scheme)://(something) and not just (scheme):(something) asiri - (24/11/2008 13:31): he he vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:31): this is different vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:31): since in your example above it's a URL not a URI asiri - (24/11/2008 13:31): right. vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:32): ok I know what the pb is vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:32): wikimodel is indeed passing this as a reference token to us vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:32): we parse it and since we don't recognize a valid URI we consider that "code:\*\*" is a reference asiri - (24/11/2008 13:33): i didn't know the difference between a uri and a url .. :P vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:33): asiri: can you create a jira issue for this please? vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:33): (a url is a special uri) vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:33): see http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/net/URI.html asiri - (24/11/2008 13:34): a URI can be either a URN or a URL is that correct ? vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:34): A URI is a uniform resource identifier while a URL is a uniform resource locator. Hence every URL is a URI, abstractly speaking, but not every URI is a URL. This is because there is another subcategory of URIs, uniform resource names (URNs), which name resources but do not specify how to locate them. The mailto, news, and isbn URIs shown above are examples of URNs. asiri - (24/11/2008 13:35): got it :) asiri - (24/11/2008 13:35): vmassol: should the jira be about this specific scenario or a more generic one ? vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:36): asiri: it should be about inline reference pointing to unknown URIs vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:36): which we should leave as normal text and not references vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:36): you can use your example in the jira issue vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:36): don't worry I'll fix the subject if need be vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:36): (asiri) asiri - (24/11/2008 13:36): vmassol: what do you mean by a reference ? sorry, should i know that already ? asiri - (24/11/2008 13:36): :) vmassol\_ - (24/11/2008 13:37): a reference is either a link or an image in our syntax asiri - (24/11/2008 13:37): oki doki, now i get it, thanks.
